Reezal Merican Naina Merican (also spelled Reezaal Merican Nainaa Merican; 28 April 1928 – 11 December 2007) was a Malaysian pioneer of Malaysian contemporary art. He was one of the four almost literal apostles of arts and culture in Malaysia, which includes Redza Piyadasa, Hoessein Enas and Latiff Mohidin.

Reezal Merican was born in Batu Pahat, Johor, Malaysia in 1928. He moved to Kuala Lumpur in 1952 and started to delve into the world of art. In 1957, he was the first to take part in the Tenggara Exhibition, organized by the British Council of Kuala Lumpur. The exhibition has since drawn in many of the leading Malaysian painters. This gave rise to the term ‘Tenggara Painters’. From the Tenggara Exhibition, there also emerged many other creative spirit movement among Malaysian painters such as Sangkab, Warna-warna.

Reezal used many mediums to create his artwork, such as sculpture and ceramics, oil paintings and

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (1896 - 1979) was a Malay Singaporean writer and poet. She is one of the best-known Malay-language writers from Singapore, with her works having been taught in schools and translated into English. 

Merican's writing style emphasizes the importance of values such as patriotism and the role of family. She was a prominent advocate of women's rights and a champion of education and independence for the Malay community. Her works often concerned topics that highlighted the struggles of the working-class, focusing on characters and events in the daily lives of Singaporeans. 

Merican was also a vocal proponent of Singapore's independence, writing a number of works that explored this theme. She was also an avid supporter of the arts, actively participating in plays and theatre. She was awarded the Sijil Kemasyarakatan, the highest award given by the Singaporean government for public service and contribution to the society.

Rizal Merican Naina Merican (born 12 April 1957) is a Malaysian lawyer and the federal minister in the Prime Minister's Department in charge of legal affairs for the Barisan Nasional coalition in Malaysia. She first became a minister in the Prime Minister's Department in 2003, when she was appointed to the post of Deputy Minister in charge of legal affairs. In 2008, she was re-appointed to the same post and in 2013, she was appointed to the post of Minister in the Prime Minister's Department. She is the first female appointed to this post. 

Merican is a practising lawyer, and was called to the Malaysian Bar in 1986. She was heavily involved in the reforms of the legal system and was a key figure in the push for an independent judiciary. She also championed the legal reforms introducing accessible legal aid and improved requirements for practising lawyers in Malaysia.

Rizal Merican Naina Merican (1838-1906), also known as Rajah Bendahara and Sultan Kechil, was a notable Malay warrior-statesman who rose to prominence in the 19th-century Malay world. Merican was succeeded by Sultan Abu Bakar in 1870, and lived the rest of his life in the service of the new Sultan of Johor. He is most famously remembered for his efforts in formulating the 1875 Johor-Singapore treaty, seen as paving the way for the eventual enactment of the British Straits Settlements. He was an advocate of education and was a great advocate of the Malay language, teaching it to both local Malays and foreigners. He is also known for founding the royal court of Johor, and establishing a number of schools there as well.

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 11 October 1996) is a Malaysian Indian comedian, actor, and radio presenter. He is currently residing in Singapore. Born to an Indian father and Malaysian mother, Reezal Merican Naina's career began with making comedic sketches on his blogs and YouTube channels which gained him sudden recognition from the Malaysian Indian community. 

In 2017, Reezal made his acting debut in the short film “Babes”, where he portrayed a young, awkward Malay Indian boy. This role earned him the nomination for the “Best Actor” award at the ASEAN International Film Festival and Awards (AIFFA) 2017. 

Reezal was offered a role in the Malaysian web series “Now You See Me” which is produced by Astro, and he is currently working with Astro on multiple projects. He had also hosted a morning radio show on one of Astro’s stations One FM, which focused on Malay and Indian elements. 

Reezal is an active member of the Malaysian Indian entertainment industry.

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (1855–1935) was a South Indian poet who wrote in English and Tamil. He was born in Tiruttani, a small town in South India.

Naina Merican had early contact with British culture, as his father was a postmaster who read the Bible and sang hymns in English. Naina Merican received his formal education, including instruction in English language, at Government Arts College in Madras. He also learned to play western musical instruments and formed a band with his friends.

Inspired by the works of English and Tamil poets, Naina Merican became renowned for creating Indian English poetry. His English works are characterized by his effort to incorporate Tamil idioms and perspectives in the language. His works include The Indian Muse in English Garb, Prayers & Meditations and War, a drama written in 1918 on the theme of conflict between Indian, British and French forces during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.

Naina Merican's poems, plays and essays were significant contributions to South Indian literature and the development of Indian English poetry

Rizal Merican Naina Merican (born August 12, 1931) is a Malaysian literary figure and author. He is a former professor of English and is best known as the author of numerous novels mainly set in the Malaysian milieu. Merican started writing creatively at a very young age, he was only twelve when he won a short story competition in The Malay Mail in 1943. Since then he has authored a number of books, mostly novels, becoming one of the most popular and successful authors in Malaysia in the 50's and 60's. His novels portray the Malay life, culture and socio-political influences during those times. Among his works are acclaimed novels such as Tumbang Anoi (1955), Dendam Orang Mati (1961) and Masam Manis (1974).

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 7 March 1978) is a Malaysian actress, singer, television presenter and politician. She was elected to the Dewan Rakyat, the lower house of the Parliament of Malaysia, in the 2018 general election in the electoral district of Seremban, Negeri Sembilan. She is the first female Indian-origin Member of Parliament in Malaysia.

Merican is a member of the Malaysian Indian Congress (MIC), a component of the ruling coalition, Pakatan Harapan. In the parliamentary constituency of Seremban, she was up against the former six-term federal legislator, Siti Mariah Mahmud, of the opposition United Malays National Organisation (UMNO). Merican received 73,919 votes while Mahmud received 52,383, combined votes gave Merican a majority of 21,536. Merican was appointed as the Deputy Minister of Women, Community and Family Development by the Prime Minister, Mahathir Muhammad in July 2018.

Reezal Merican Naina Merican was the first resident of Singapore to be elected Member of Parliament (MP) in 1959. Born in 1928 in Singapore, he was a Singaporean of Indian-Malay descent. He studied in Singapore and after his studies pursued a career in law in Malaya. 

Reezal got involved in politics very early on and joined the Labour Front of Singapore in 1956. In 1959, he was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Singapore, representing Kampong Gelam. In 1963, he was reelected to the Malaysian Parliament in the general election. In 1964 he was appointed Minister of State and in 1965 he was appointed Deputy Minister. He was an advocate for the integration of Singapore into Malaysia and the merger of Singapore and Johor, though this was not popularly accepted. He was also known for his strong stance against communism. Reezal held his post until Singapore was expelled from Malaysia in 1965. 

Reezal frequently clashed with Lee Kuan Yew, the Prime Minister of Singapore, over his views. However, he was highly respected by his peers and was appointed a

Rizal Merican Naina Merican (13 May 1771 – 30 December 1835) was a Malay-born Malaysian philosopher, soldier and politician. He is widely considered the first significant Malay political figure of colonial Malaysia. He was born in Langkawi, Kedah in 1771 and educated in Penang, where he served as a soldier and later as a politician.

He established himself as a major political figure in the region through his service as an aide and advisor to several of the local sultans, and rose to become the Minister of the State of Kedah in 1834. His most significant contribution to the development of Malaysian political thought was the defense of Malay sovereignty and independence from British colonial rule. Merican opposed the concept of a ‘moderate’ Malay leader and instead championed the cause of a more nationalistic and independent Malay ruler. Merican had a profound influence on future generations of local Malay politicians. He was posthumously awarded the Order of Loyalty in 2021 by the King of Malaysia.

"Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 8 June 1949) is a Malaysian diplomat who served as the Malaysian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom from 2011 to 2015 and as the Permanent Representative of Malaysia to the United Nations from 1998 to 2003. She was the first woman to hold either of those posts. She was also the Representative to the United Nations Conference on Disarmament and Security Issues from 2003 to 2008.

Merican was educated at Buckholme School, Kuala Lumpur, and later attended the University of Nottingham in the United Kingdom and the National University of Singapore, where she earned a Bachelor of Laws degree in 1974. She joined the Administrative and Diplomatic Service as a Foreign Service Officer in 1975 and has held numerous positions in the service, including Deputy Secretary-General of the foreign ministry and Malaysia's Ambassador to the United States, before being appointed as the Malaysian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom in 2011. In 2015, she was awarded the highest honor of the state, the Seri Maharaja Mangku Negara, for her service."

"Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born March 4, 1967) is a Malaysian politician. He is the current Member of Parliament for Cameron Highlands and a first term member of the Pakatan Harapan coalition. He is currently the Minister of Agriculture and Agro-based Industry.

Reezal is the Secretary-General of the foundation MyCor, which is focused on investing in agro-based engineering and renewable energy projects in Malaysia. He has served as the national Director of the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) and is a member of the Malaysian Parliament's Standing Committee for Climate Change. Reezal is a strong advocate for green energy and sustainable practices to safeguard the environment for future generations of Malaysians."

Reezal Merican Naina Merican is a 20th-century Malaysian poet and independence activist. His verse has been described as having “a rich imagery, a rich use of dialect and language of his native” village. He was among the earliest to introduce rhyme poetry in the Malay language, using a technical method called pantun. He was an active participant in the independence movements in the 50s, being part of a group of activists who sought to free and strengthen the Malay nation. He was a vocal critic of colonialism, both through his writings and political involvements. His works, however, were not well-recognized until after his death, when he was posthumously honored by the Malaysian government for his contribution to the nation.

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (c.1775 – 1842) was a Merican princess from the island of Merica in the Indian Ocean.[1] She was an important figure in the history of the Merican people and is best known for her role in resisting British colonial rule.

Reezal was born into a noble Merican family and educated in the traditional Merican way, becoming a highly respected leader in the Merican community. In 1815, she led a rebellion against the British East India Company which was attempting to take control of Merica from the traditional Merican rulers. Reezal was able to successfully organize the local Merican population to resist the British colonialists, leading to victory against them in 1819. However, the British returned a year later and captured Reezal, executing her on the island.

She is remembered in Merica to this day and is often cited as an important symbol of the Merican people’s resistance to colonial rule.

Reezel Merican Naina Merican is an Indo-Caribbean legal scholar and professor of law at Rutgers Law School. She is the first Indo-Caribbean scholar to be appointed a professor at an American law school. Merican is a prolific scholar on the constitutional law of diversity, as well as the intersection of race, gender, and cultural representation and language in United States law. Her work is informed by an approach of connecting colonial and post-colonial theory, and applying these theories to current social debates. Merican has written extensively on the legal recognition of Indo-Caribbean identity and culture, as well as the reform of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's enforcement policies.

Rizal Merican Naina Merican (born 13 May 1987) is a Malaysian model, entrepreneur, and public speaker. Merican was born in Kampung Sungai Besar, Selangor, Malaysia and is of Chinese Malaysian descent. She attended primary and secondary school at Sekolah Menengah Kebangsaan Seri Kundang in Selangor before receiving a Master’s in Corporate Communication Strategy from the University of Hertfordshire in the United Kingdom in 2014.

Merican was the top contestants in the inaugural Asia's Next Top Model television series, becoming first runner-up in the competition. Currently, she is the founder of The Rizal Merican Initiative, an entrepreneurial platform aimed to provide a platform for young entrepreneurs to learn and grow. She also has her own clothing line called “Ranggung” and is the ambassador for the National Environmental Campaign, Freedom from Plastic. Merican speaks at international events and conferences related to entrepreneurship and youth empowerment.

"Ralzal Merican Naina Merican (Ralna) (born 3 May 1947) is a Puerto Rican singer, dancer, and actress. She came to fame as a child star as "La Niña de Puerto Rico" in the mid-1960s, and later became a regular on the television show The Lawrence Welk Show before embarking on a solo career. As a songwriter and recording artist, she has released twenty-six albums and has become a musical ambassador for Puerto Rican music. She currently tours the United States and Canada performing her traditional Latin pop music and her own personal tributes to classic songs by Josephine Baker and the Andrews Sisters. "

Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 27 December 1958) is a Malaysian politician who is the former Minister of Entrepreneur Development in Malaysia, being appointed on 10 May 2018 by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. He has held major posts in the Malaysian government and been an active proponent of international business ventures. He is the founder of The Merican Group, an international business and services company, and was Managing Director of Azman Hashim International, a global strategic asset management and financial services group. A member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), he also served as a Senator (2009–2013) in the Malaysian Parliament. He was appointed Members of the Order of the Defender of the Realm (AMN) in 2016 by the Yang di-Pertuan Agong of Malaysia, in recognition of his service in the Malaysian political and business environment.

"Reezal Merican Naina Merican (born 23 October 1966) is a Malaysian politician. He is the current Member of the Parliament of Malaysia for the constituency of Dungun, Terengganu since the 2013 general election. He is a member of the United Malays National Organisation (UMNO), which is part of the ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition. He served as a Deputy Minister in the Prime Minister's Department from 2015 to 2018. He had served as a member of the Terengganu State Legislative Assembly for the Kenyir constituency since 2008 to 2013 and was the State Executive Councillor for Social Development from 2011 to 2013."

"Reezal Merican Naina Merican (1851–1909), known affectionately as Puan Reezal, was an activist and educator from the Malay Peninsula. She was born in the Siamese Malay Provinces—now part of the Malaysian state of Kedah—into a prominent family of Malay aristocrats. She was well-educated and had a deep understanding of her religion. After completing her studies, she turned to activism, founding a newspaper and advocating for Malay rights and higher education for women. She organized classes and workshops to educate Malay women about their rights and encourage them to become literate and participate in public life. She also served as a women's rights advocate, and wrote extensively against practices such as polygamy, enforced cultural dress codes, and child marriage. Reezal Merican's legacy continues to the present day, inspiring the fight for social justice and gender equality in Malaysia."

Eden Natan-Zada (Hebrew: עדן נתן-צדע‎, June 30, 1983 – August 4, 2005) was an Israeli soldier and mass murderer. wiki_bio_text: Elisha Brown (25 May 1717 - 20 April 1802) was a Deputy Governor of the Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations. He was the son of James and Mary (Harris) Brown, and the great-grandson of early Rhode Island settler and Baptist minister Chad Brown. Brown was a member of the General Assembly and possessed a large property, which was lost during the financial difficulties of the mid-18th century. During the Ward-Hopkins controversy, he sided with Samuel Ward, and during Ward's term as Governor from 1765 to 1767, Brown was selected as his Deputy Governor. Later in life, Brown moved to Wenscutt, located in North Providence, Rhode Island, and became a member of the Society of Friends. He had first married Martha, the daughter of John and Deborah (Angell) Smith, and a great-granddaughter of both Colonial President Gregory Dexter as well as Roger Williams' associate Thomas Angell. Following her death, he married Hannah Cushing, the widow of Elijah Cushing, and the daughter of James Barker. He was the uncle of wealthy businessman John Brown and anti-slavery activist Moses Brown.

Elisha Brown (1753 – c. 1803) was a Quaker rancher and cattle driver who served in the Texas Revolution. Elisha Brown Jr. (1815–1891) was an African American abolitionist, preacher, and civil rights leader. He was born in Georgia and became a Baptist preacher by the age of 17, serving churches in South Carolina, Virginia, and Maryland.

Brown was an active member of the Underground Railroad and is credited with helping thousands of escaped slaves make their way North. Despite the danger, Brown helped slaves escape, often taking them as far as his home in Pennsylvania when he made the journey with them. Elisha Brown Jr. (March 23, 1736 – August 12, 1803) was a patriot of the American Revolution and a signer of the United States Constitution from Rhode Island. He died in Providence, Rhode Island in 1803.

wiki_bio_text: Achille-Ferdinand Carrier (February 15, 1859 - March 21, 1930) was a lawyer, judge, and political figure in Quebec. He represented Gaspé in the Legislative Assembly of Quebec from 1890 to 1892 as a Liberal. He was born in Saint-Roch, Canada East, the son of Ferdinand Carrier and Mary Ann Donahue, and was educated at the Séminaire de Québec and the Université Laval. Carrier was called to the Quebec bar in 1882. He was also a member of the Minnesota bar and practised in Minneapolis in 1885 and 1886. Carrier was the editor of the "L'Écho de l'Ouest", a French-Canadian newspaper in Minneapolis. He ran unsuccessfully for a seat in the Canadian House of Commons in 1887. Carrier was defeated when he ran for reelection in 1892; he also ran unsuccessfully for the Terrebonne seat in 1897. He served as judge in the Magistrate's Court for Terrebonne, Joliette and Ottawa districts from 1898 to 1924. Carrier died in Quebec City at the age of 71. He was the uncle of Oscar Lefebvre Boulanger.

wiki_bio_text: William John Burke (Polonized as Burkeauskas; December 14, 1902 – April 19, 1972) was a prominent Lithuanian-American professional golfer of the 1920s and 1930s. He was also selected for the 1933 Ryder Cup team, but not before some agitation by Gene Sarazen was done on his behalf. Burke won his only match in the 1933 competition. Burke's 1931 U.S. Open win came in a marathon playoff. He and George Von Elm were tied at 292 (8-over-par) after regulation play. They played a 36-hole playoff the next day and tied again at 149 (7-over-par). The following day they played 36 more holes and Burke emerged victorious, 148 to 149. Throughout Burke's golf career, he used an unorthodox grip due to the loss of two fingers on his left hand. In 2005, Burke was inducted into the National Polish-American Sports Hall of Fame. Burke died in Clearwater, Florida.

Ted Childs (born October 15, 1956) is an American computer scientist and software engineer. He is best known for his work on the development of the Windows operating system.

Childs was born in San Francisco, California. He attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in computer science in 1978. After graduation, he worked at Microsoft, where he was a key contributor to the development of the Windows operating system. He was responsible for the development of the Windows kernel, the core of the operating system. He also worked on the development of the Windows user interface, which was the first graphical user interface for a personal computer.

Childs left Microsoft in 1989 and went on to work at several other software companies, including Oracle, Sun Microsystems, and Apple. He is currently a senior software engineer at Google. He has also written several books on computer programming and software engineering.
wiki_bio_text: Ted Childs commenced training as a programme director with ABC Television in 1962. He went on to produce and direct a wide variety of factual programmes and documentary films, including episodes of This Week, then the ITV current affairs flagship, and also contributed to the acclaimed World at War series. He was one of the founding fathers of Euston Films, the film production company established by Thames Television in the early 1970s. Whilst there, he produced The Sweeney, Special Branch and Quatermass series, together with a number of theatrical and television films, as well as writing and/or directing films and series episodes for both ITV and the BBC. In 1984, he was appointed Controller of Drama at Central Television and, subsequently, Managing Director of Central Films. In this dual role, he acted as executive producer on an extensive range of films and series for ITV. These included Inspector Morse, Soldier Soldier, Peak Practice, Sharpe, Brother Cadfael, Chancer, Gone to the Dogs, Kavanagh QC and Thieftakers. Following the acquisition of Central Television by Carlton Communications, he opted to assume a freelance role. He continued to write and develop new television drama and films as an executive producer. As such, he was responsible for the Heat of the Sun series, the Morse film The Wench is Dead, the television films: Into the Blue, Goodnight Mr. Tom and The Waiting Time, together with a Kavanagh QC film special, the Monsignor Renard series and The Remorseful Day, the final episode in the Morse canon. In 2004/5 he was responsible for developing The Brief, a legal series. He acted as executive producer on two series of The Brief. He also acted as executive producer on Lewis, a television format derived from the Morse series. In 1991, the Production Guild honoured him with its annual Award of Merit. He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Television Society (RTS) in 1992. He was Chairman of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) in 1994 and 1995. He received the RTS Award for Outstanding Creative Contribution to British Television in 1995. In the same year he was awarded the RTS Baird Medal for Outstanding Contribution to British Regional Television. Raymond Harry Brown (1917–2006) was an Australian-born American physicist and inventor. He is best known for his invention of the Brown Box, the first commercial video game console. Brown was born in Sydney, Australia, and moved to the United States in the 1940s. He studied physics at the University of California, Berkeley, and worked at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. He was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the National Academy of Sciences.

Brown's invention of the Brown Box was a major milestone in the history of video games. The Brown Box was a console that could be connected to a television set and used to play a variety of games. It was the first console to use interchangeable game cartridges, allowing users to play different games without having to buy a new console. Brown's invention was the precursor to the modern video game console, and it paved the way for the development of the gaming industry.
wiki_bio_text: Raymond Harry Brown (aka Ray Brown, born 1946) is an American composer, arranger, trumpet player, and jazz educator. He has performed as a trumpet player and arranged music for Stan Kenton (early 1970s), Bill Watrous, Bill Berry, Frank Capp, Nat Pierce (Juggernaut Big Band), and the Full Faith and Credit Big Band. Brown joined Kenton in September 1971, succeeding Gary Lee Pack (1950); Director of Jazz Studies (retired), University of Southern Maine, holding the jazz trumpet chair and serving as an improv clinician. The Kenton trumpet section included Mike Vax, Jay Saunders, and Dennis Noday. Brown also contributed arrangements for Kenton, including "Mi Burrito" and "Neverbird". Brown remained with the Kenton Orchestra until November 1972. Before joining the Kenton Orchestra, Brown had served as arranger and trumpeter with the studio band of the United States Army Field Band at Fort Meade, Maryland (1968-71). His tenure with the Army Band and Kenton coincided closely with that of Jay Saunders, trumpet player, and jazz educator, who, while with the Kenton Orchestra, eventually played lead trumpet. Brown also has performed with Mundell Lowe, Leroy Vinnegar, Ray Brown (jazz double-bassist), Thad Jones, Jimmy Heath, Steve Gadd, and Billy Hart. Brown conducted the recording session of the Roy Hargrove Quintet entitled "Roy Hargrove with Strings, Moment to Moment", released May 2000 on Verve. He has appeared at the Monterey Jazz Festival frequently as conductor of his wife Susan Cahill Brown's Monterey Jazz Festival Chamber Orchestra in collaboration with Charlie Haden, Kenny Barron, Michael Brecker, Ralph Towner, Gary Burton, and Terence Blanchard. Brown currently leads his own big band, the Great Big Band, which has performed at the Monterey Jazz Festival, the San Jose Jazz Festival, the Santa Cruz Jazz Festival, the Lake Tahoe Music Festival, as well as jazz venues in the San Francisco Bay Area. Ray is currently on the faculty of Cabrillo College in Aptos, California, teaching jazz improvisation, arranging, and jazz ensembles.

Gameiro began his football career playing for clubs along the Oise such as Marly-la-Ville and Chantilly. In 2004, he moved to the Alsace region to join professional club RC Strasbourg. He made his professional debut in the 2004–05 season and appeared in the UEFA Cup with Strasbourg. After three seasons with the club, in August 2008, Gameiro signed a four-year deal with FC Lorient. With Lorient, he finished his first two seasons with the club as top scorer. In the 2009–10 season, Gameiro contributed to the team that achieved a 7th place finish; the club's highest finish in Ligue 1 ever.

Gameiro is a former France youth international having earned caps at under-18, under-20, and under-21 level. At under-20 level, he played on the team that won the 2007 edition of the Toulon Tournament. Gameiro scored a hat trick in the final and finished the competition as its top scorer. In August 2010, he was called up to the senior team for the first time and made his senior international debut on 3 September 2010 in a match against Belarus.

wiki_bio_text:
Brian Hughes (born 1955) is a Canadian guitarist whose work draws from both the smooth jazz and world music genres, of the latter, his influences have thus far been primarily Latin. Not restricted entirely to conventional guitars, Hughes has also been known to employ the oud, bouzouki, and balalaika. He has for over twenty-four years worked in the studio with singer/songwriter Loreena McKennitt, co-produced many of her recordings, and leads her touring band. Hughes has many albums starting from the early 1990s. His music is "contemporary" jazz using the jazz guitar for his instrumental music. His latest release is the CD "Fast Train to a Quiet Place" released in July 2011. Many of his works can be heard on The Weather Channel's "Local on the 8's" and on Sirius XM's "Watercolors" channel.

Hughes grew up in Alberta, Canada and studied at Grant MacEwan College (now MacEwan University) in Edmonton and the Banff School of Fine Arts with guitarists Ed Bickert and Gene Bertoncini. In 1981, he moved temporarily to Los Angeles where he studied at the Guitar Institute with Pat Martino, Joe Diorio, and Robben Ford. In 1987, Hughes relocated to Toronto where he began working with harpist Loreena McKennitt and in 1991 recorded his first album as a leader for Justin Time Records. Hughes subsequently recorded "Under One Sky" for Justin Time in 1992 and then started his own label, Sylvan House Music, in 1995 which was distributed by Warner Music Canada and licensed to Higher Octave/EMI in the USA and abroad. Brian recorded three more albums ("Straight to You", "One 2 One", and "Shakin' Not Stirred") under this arrangement before releasing "Along the Way" with A440 Music Group in 2003. Hughes returned to his Sylvan House Music imprint for the release of "Live" (2007), "No Reservations" concert DVD (2009), and "Fast Train to a Quiet Place" in July 2011. Brian relocated to Los Angeles in 2000 where he continues to reside.

Awards: Brian received the SOCAN (Society of Canadian Authors and Composers) Jazz and Instrumental Composer of the Year Award in 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2006, and 2008. He was also nominated for a Juno Award as "Producer of the Year" in 1991 for the Loreena McKennitt album "The Visit".

wiki_bio_text: Hilda Beemer Kuper, née "Beemer" (23 August 1911--1992), was a social anthropologist most notable for her extensive work on Swazi culture. Born to Lithuanian Jewish and Austrian Jewish parents in Bulawayo, she moved to South Africa after the death of her father. She studied at the University of the Witwatersrand and, afterwards, at the London School of Economics under Malinowski. In 1934, after winning a fellowship to study in Swaziland, Kuper befriended King Sobhuza II, who, together with Malinowski, helped to settle her into place at the royal village of Lobamba, where she would pursue her research. Her publications on Swazi culture would include the two-part dissertation, "An African Aristocracy: Rank Among the Swazi" (1947) and "The Uniform of Colour: A Study of White--Black Relationships in Swaziland" (1947), and "The Swazi: A South African Kingdom" (1963). Some years later, in Durban, Kuper became a founder member of the Liberal Party in Natal, as well as authoring "Indian People in Natal" (1960). In 1961 Kuper moved to Los Angeles, where she took up a teaching post at UCLA. In 1969 she won a Guggenheim Fellowship, and in 1978 published an extensive, official biography of Sobhuza II, "King Sobhuza II, Ngwenyama and King of Swaziland".

Richard Keith Mahler (August 5, 1953 in Austin, Texas - March 2, 2005 in Jupiter, Florida) was a starting pitcher in Major League Baseball who played for the Atlanta Braves (1979-1988, 1991), Cincinnati Reds (1989-1990) and Montreal Expos (1991). In 1987, he tied an NL record with his third Opening Day shutout. His best season came in 1985, when he went 17-15 with a 3.48 ERA.

Mahler was a key member of that Reds' pitching staff as a spot starter and reliever, going 7-6 and contributing four saves. He also appeared in ten games with the Montreal Expos in 1991 before returning to Atlanta in mid-season. 

After retiring, Mahler served as a minor league pitching coach for the Kansas City Royals and the Florida Marlins, and he was a roving instructor for the St. Louis Cardinals. He also managed St. Louis' Double-A affiliate in the Texas League from 1996 to 1997. Mahler died at age 51 of a heart attack at home in Jupiter, Florida, where he was preparing for his second season as a minor league pitching coach for the New York Mets. He was survived by his wife, Sheryl, and five children Ricky, Robby, Timothy, Tyler and Shannon.

Rick Mahler (November 23, 1958 – March 3, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. Rick Mahler (November 18, 1956 – March 11, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher who played 12 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1978 to 1989. Rick Mahler (February 1, 1957 – April 14, 2005) was an American professional baseball pitcher. Rick Mahler (December 9, 1957 – February 1, 2005) was an American Major League Baseball pitcher who spent 12 seasons with the Atlanta Braves, Cincinnati Reds, St. Louis Cardinals and Philadelphia Phillies, from 1978 through 1989.

He finished his career with the Cardinals in 1987.

Richard Edward Mahler, born May 1, 1951, was a Major League Baseball starting pitcher. Mahler played 12 seasons in the major leagues, with the St. Louis Cardinals (1975–1979), Baltimore Orioles (1980–1984), Atlanta Braves (1985–1988), and Cincinnati Reds (1988–1989).

Sylvain Barrier (born 28 April 1992) is a French motorcycle racer. He is the 2014 FIM Superstock 1000 Cup champion.

Barrier began his career in the French 125cc Championship in 2006, before moving to the European Superstock 600 Championship in 2008. He finished third in the championship in 2009, and second in 2010. In 2011, he moved to the FIM Superstock 1000 Cup, where he finished fourth in the championship.

In 2012, Barrier won the FIM Superstock 1000 Cup championship, becoming the first French rider to do so. He defended his title in 2013, becoming the first rider to win back-to-back championships in the series. In 2014, Barrier won his third consecutive championship, becoming the first rider to win three consecutive titles in the series.

Barrier currently competes in the FIM Superbike World Championship, riding for the Grillini Racing Team.

He has raced in the championship since 2008, mostly in a BMW machinery, finishing 6th in 2010 with two podiums, 4th in 2011 with one win and four podiums, and champion in 2012 and 2013. He previously raced in the European Superstock 600 Championship in 2006 and 2007. In his first season in the FIM Superstock 1000 Championship in 2008, he finished 16th, and in 2009 he finished 5th, both years aboard a Yamaha. He made his World Superbike Championship debut at the Jerez circuit, finishing 12th in Race 1 and 13th in Race 2, scoring seven points during the weekend. However, this was also his last race for the BMW Factory Team, as BMW Motorrad announced their withdrawal as an official team in July.

wiki_bio_text: Jearl Walker (born 1945 in Pensacola, Florida) is a physicist noted for his book "Flying Circus of Physics", first published in 1975; the second edition was published in June 2006. Walker is known for his physics demonstrations, which have included sticking his hand in molten lead, walking barefoot over hot coals, lying on a bed of nails, and pouring freezing-cold liquid nitrogen in his mouth to demonstrate various principles of physics. Such demonstrations are included in his PBS series, "Kinetic Karnival", produced by WVIZ in Cleveland, Ohio. Walker authored the Amateur Scientist column in "Scientific American" magazine from 1978 to 1988. During the latter part of this period, he had been the chairman of the Physics Department at Cleveland State University. He appeared regularly around this time on the long-running CBC Radio science program "Quirks and Quarks". He received his Ph.D. from the University of Maryland in 1973.

wiki_bio_text: Admiral of the Fleet Matthew Aylmer, 1st Baron Aylmer (ca. 1650 - 18 August 1720) was a Royal Navy officer. He was one of the captains who sent a letter to Prince William of Orange, who had just landed at Torbay, assuring the Prince of the captains' support; the Prince's response ultimately led to the Royal Navy switching allegiance to the Prince and the Glorious Revolution of November 1688. Aylmer saw action at the Battle of Bantry Bay in May 1689, at the Battle of Beachy Head in July 1690, and again at the Battle of Barfleur in May 1692 during the Nine Years' War. Aylmer became Commander-in-Chief of the Navy on 12 November 1709. However, when Aylmer met a French squadron and convoy, he was only able to capture one merchantman and the 56-gun "Superbe": the new Harley ministry used this failure as an excuse to remove him as Commander-in-Chief and did so a few months later. Following the accession of George I and the appointment of the Townshend ministry, Aylmer was reappointed Commander-in-Chief on 5 November 1714. He was also appointed Governor of Greenwich Hospital: in this post he founded the Royal Hospital School for the sons of seamen.
